elements.content: Early screening of Salmonella is of utmost importance to minimize the incidence of related foodborne diseases. Here, we reported an immunosensor to fast detect Salmonella using Fe-MIL-88NH2 metal–organic framework (Fe-MOF) nanocubes to load platinum nanoparticles (PtNPs) for signal amplification and smartphone thermal imaging to monitor the temperature change. The Fe-MOF nanocubes decorated with PtNPs (Fe-MOF/PtNPs) were prepared as peroxidase mimics to catalyze hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) to produce O2. The immune magnetic nanoparticles (MNPs), the target bacteria, and the immune Fe-MOF/PtNPs were first mixed by the three-dimensional (3D) chaotic micromixer and conjugated in the microfluidic chip to form MNP–bacteria–Fe-MOF/PtNPs sandwich complexes. After magnetic separation and washing, H2O2 was injected and decomposed by Fe-MOF/PtNPs on the sandwich complexes to generate O2 in a sealed chamber. The increase in the pressure pushed the preloaded water to react with calcium oxide powder, resulting in the generation of heat, which was measured using the smartphone-based thermal sensor to determine the bacteria. The microfluidic immunosensor could detect Salmonella as low as 93 CFU/mL within 1 h.

Introduction

Over decades, the incidence of foodborne diseases caused by pathogens has drastically increased worldwide, resulting in severe public health issues and enormous economic losses. The World Health Organization (WHO) estimated that nearly 1 in 10 people suffer from foodborne diseases in the world each year, and 33 million of healthy life years are lost annually. Among foodborne pathogens, the infections caused by Salmonella is the highest, and Salmonella is one of the four main global causes of diarrhea. However, currently available methods for Salmonella detection are subject to some limitations, such as long time (Culture), complex nucleic acid extraction (polymerase chain reaction, PCR), and insufficient sensitivity (enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay, ELISA). Hence, in-field, fast, and sensitive methods to detect Salmonella in foods are urgently needed.

elements.content: Various biosensors have been widely reported for pathogens detection over the past years. Among these methods, the electrochemical biosensors and optical biosensors have received extensive attention because of their fast analysis, good reliability, and high sensitivity. Nevertheless, most of these biosensors rely on sophisticated equipment, such as an electrochemical workstation, microplate reader, and spectrophotometer, which greatly limit their in-field applications. In recent years, some novel biosensors based on smartphone and other portable devices (such as glucose meters, pressure meters, pH meters, thermometers, etc.) have been developed with the merits of high accuracy, easy operation, and low price. An interesting study was reported using a universal pressure meter as a readout for determination. The pressure meter was utilized to measure the pressure change caused by O2, which was generated from the reaction of nanozyme with hydrogen peroxide (H2O2). Another interesting study was reported using a common thermometer to develop a thermal biosensor for DNA detection. The thermometer was inserted into the solution to measure the temperature change resulting from 2 to 18 °C. This biosensor could detect DNA as low as 0.28 nM. Recently, some emerging thermal sensors have become commercially available at low cost and could be connected with a smartphone for measuring the temperature change, which might be an alternative for in-field detection of Salmonella.

elements.content: To achieve satisfactory sensitivity, some signal probes, such as enzymes, nanomaterials, and chemical molecules, were often used to amplify the signals. Among them, nanozymes have attracted increasing attention and been considered as an excellent choice to replace natural enzymes due to their superior properties, such as low cost, high stability, and mass production. Platinum nanoparticles (PtNPs) are one kind of catalase mimic and often used to catalyze H2O2 to produce O2. Recently, some metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), like Fe-MOF, have been reported with unique enzyme-mimic property and extraordinarily high surface area. An interesting study was reported by depositing gold nanoparticles on Fe-MIL-88 to develop a multifunctional catalyst with enhanced catalytic performance for DNA detection. Therefore, it is worthy to attempt Fe-MOF/PtNPs for the dual-signal amplification in the development of new biosensors.

elements.content: To further simplify the operation, shorten the time and reduce the cost, various microfluidic chips have been developed for pathogens detection due to their unique advantages of automatic fluid control, miniaturized size, less detection time, and low cost. Mixing is the key component of a microfluidic chip because the fluids are basically laminar in microfluidic channels. The chaotic micromixers have drawn increasing attention due to their excellent mixing performance. Recently, an interesting chaotic micromixer was developed based on a layer-by-layer structure to achieve excellent mixing over a wide range of Reynolds numbers. Therefore, the integration of smartphone-based thermal sensor, microfluidic chip, and Fe-MOF/PtNPs nanozyme might be promising to establish in-field, fast, and cost-effective methods to detect Salmonella. Here, we proposed a microfluidic immunosensor to detect Salmonella using Fe-MOF/PtNPs as a signal amplifier, a smartphone-based thermal sensor as a signal detector, and a two-layer microfluidic chip as a research platform. As can be seen in , capture antibodies (CAbs, marked in green) coated magnetic nanoparticles (MNPs), Salmonella, detection antibodies (DAbs, marked in purple) modified Fe-MOF/PtNPs were injected into the chip at the same time, efficiently mixed by the three-dimensional (3D) chaotic micromixer and sufficiently incubated in the incubation channel, leading to the formation of the MNP–Salmonella–Fe-MOF/PtNPs sandwich complexes. Then, a magnet was used to capture the complexes in a separation chamber. Finally, H2O2 was injected and decomposed by the nanozyme on the sandwich complexes to produce oxygen (O2) in the sealed chamber. The increase in the pressure in the separation chamber pushed the preloaded water (H2O) into the heating chamber with calcium oxide (CaO) powder to produce heat, which was measured by the smartphone-based thermal sensor to determine the amount of Salmonella.

Thus, the mixing efficiency of this 3D chaotic micromixer was estimated by the COMSOL software. As can be seen in a,b, the simulation results show that the mixing efficiency of the micromixer is about 93%, indicating that the 3D micromixer has a good mixing effect. To evaluate the actual mixing efficiency of this micromixer, a blue dye and water were injected from the middle and both sides with the same flow rate (10 μL/min), respectively. The microscope was used to collect the images at the inlet and outlet. c shows two obvious boundary lines (Inlet), indicating that the dye at the center is separate from the water on both sides. As shown in d, the color looks uniform (outlet), indicating that blue dye has mixed well with the water. To further evaluate the mixing performance, the image processing software (Image J) was used to analyze the images. As shown in e, the gray values display three visible levels from top to bottom at the inlet. However, the gray values tend to be uniform at the outlet, further demonstrating that blue dye and water have been well mixed by the 3D micromixer. Furthermore, the mixing efficiency could be calculated by the following equation σ = 1 N − 1 ∑ i = 1 N ( X i − X̅ i ) 2 M e = 1 − σ 2 σ max 2 where σ is the standard deviation, X i is the normalized color intensity at point i, X̅ i is the average color intensity, and σmax is the maximum standard deviation at the inlet. The mixing efficiency of the micromixer was calculated as ∼80%, indicating that the immune MNPs, Salmonella, and the immune Fe-MOF/PtNPs could be well mixed through the 3D micromixer.

In summary, a microfluidic immunosensor using Fe-MOF/PtNPs as a nanozyme for signal amplification, the microfluidic chip with the 3D micromixer for automatic operations, and the smartphone-based thermal sensor for signal measurement was successfully developed.
